intro: Castilleja tapeinoclada var. hirta, commonly known as the hairy leafed Indian paintbrush, is a hemiparasitic plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Orobanchaceae family and is characterized by its bright red, tubular flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant has reduced leaves and relies on root connections to host plants for water and nutrients. It typically grows in open, sunny habitats such as grasslands and sagebrush steppe. Its unique appearance and ecological role make it a notable species in its native range.
